Pre-Game Insights: Sunil Chhetri announced that June 6 would be his last match for India, marking the end of his 19-year service.
Igor Stimac emphasized the importance of victory and the prestige of the fixture due to Chhetri's last match.
India head coach Igor Stimac believes the team is on the same page in terms of fitness and is ready for the match.
India and Kuwait have met thrice in the last 12 months, with India winning 2 and drawing 1.
India's best game against Kuwait was away in Kuwait in the World Cup Qualifiers, where they had perfect defensive shape and didn't allow Kuwait to create clear chances.
India's goal-scoring from open play has been an Achilles heel, with their last open-play goal coming against Kuwait from Manvir Singh's left foot.
India's head coach Igor Stimac is confident that the team has worked hard on details and will be ready for each scenario in the match.
Kuwait's Portuguese head coach Rui Bento believes his team is in a better place than last year and can put up a better challenge against India.
Kuwait is wary of a defeat, which will condemn them to the bottom two in the group and officially eliminate them from World Cup qualifying.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The match between India and Kuwait will be broadcast on Sports 18 1, Sports 18 1 HD, Sports 18 3, and streamed live on JioCinema.
The match will take place on June 6, 2024, at 19:00 IST.
India's victory on June 6 will put them one foot into the next round of qualifiers for the FIFA World Cup 2026 and AFC Asian Cup 2027 Preliminary Joint Qualification Round 2.
Sunil Chhetri will hang his boots at the Salt Lake Stadium after 19 years of service to the Indian national team.
Chhetri's last kick of the ball for India will be witnessed by more than 60,000 people at the Salt Lake Stadium.
Kuwait held a one-week camp in Bangkok before traveling to Kolkata on Tuesday night.
Kuwait's head coach Rui Bento named a 26-man squad composed entirely of players from the Kuwait Premier League.
